perturbation.original_text:
1.4 “Confidential Information” includes: (1) all information contained in documents marked "confidential" and disclosed by one Party (the
"disclosing party") to the other Party (the "recipient party") pursuant to this Agreement; (2) orally disclosed information which is disclosed by the
disclosing party to the recipient party pursuant to this Agreement, summarized in writing, identified as "confidential" and delivered to the recipient
party; and (3) all proprietary technical information, business and financial information, and all other information which a reasonable person would
treat confidentially that relates to the Development Products and disclosed from the disclosing party to the recipient party, whether or not the
information is marked as “confidential.” Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, CNS shall be permitted to make such disclosures as CNS
determines, in its sole discretion, is required pursuant to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, and the rules and regulations thereof.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.4 “Confidential Information” includes: (1) all information contained in documents marked "confidential" and disclosed by one Party (the
"disclosing party") to the other Party (the "recipient party") pursuant to this Agreement; (2) orally disclosed information which is disclosed by the
disclosing party to the recipient party pursuant to this Agreement, summarized in writing, identified as "confidential" and delivered to the recipient
party; and (3) all proprietary technical information, business and financial information. However, it is understood and agreed that proprietary technical, business, and financial information shall be considered non-confidential if not explicitly marked as “confidential” at the time of disclosure.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'Confidential Information' included proprietary technical, business, and financial information regardless of whether it was explicitly marked as 'confidential'. The modified definition changes this, stating that such information is only confidential if explicitly marked as such. This contradicts standard legal interpretations of confidentiality, which often protect trade secrets and sensitive business information even if not explicitly labeled.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Laws, common law principles of confidentiality

perturbation.original_text:
7.2 U.S. FCPA Compliance. WPD hereby agrees to at all times comply with the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, as amended (the
“FCPA”), and WPD shall establish, institute and maintain policies and procedures designed to ensure that:
7.2.1 no agent, employee or affiliate of WPD, or any of its affiliates, takes any action, directly or indirectly, that would result in a
violation by such person of the FCPA or any other anti-bribery or anti-corruption law, rule or regulation of similar purpose and scope, including,
without limitation, making use of the U.S. mails or any means or instrumentality of interstate commerce in furtherance of an unlawful offer, payment,
promise to pay or authorization of the unlawful payment of any money, or other property, gift, promise to give, or authorization of the giving of
anything of value to any "foreign official" or any foreign political party or official thereof, of any candidate for any foreign office or any candidate
for foreign political office, in contravention of the FCPA;
perturbation.changed_text:
7.2 U.S. FCPA Compliance. WPD hereby agrees to at all times comply with the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, as amended (the
“FCPA”), and WPD shall establish, institute and maintain policies and procedures designed to ensure that:
7.2.1 no agent, employee or affiliate of WPD, or any of its affiliates, takes any action, directly or indirectly, that would result in a
violation by such person of the FCPA only if WPD management is directly informed, with documented evidence of such action, prior to the action's execution. The duty to avoid a violation will not extend to unintentional acts.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause required WPD to ensure no violation of the FCPA. The modified version adds a condition that a violation only occurs if WPD management has documented evidence of the action beforehand and that the clause does not extend to unintentional acts. This significantly narrows the scope of compliance with the FCPA, contradicting the intent and strict liability aspects of the law. The FCPA prohibits corrupt payments, regardless of intent, if those payments are made to influence a foreign official.

perturbation.original_text: 1.5 “Development Fee” means 50% of the Net Sales for any Development Products in the Development Territory.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.5 “Development Fee” means 50% of the Net Sales for any Development Products in the Development Territory, unless WPD, in its sole discretion, determines that market conditions warrant a lower fee.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition mandated that the Development Fee be 50% of Net Sales. The added clause allows WPD to unilaterally lower the fee based on 'market conditions'. This contradicts the initial fixed percentage and introduces ambiguity and potential for disputes, effectively undermining the legally binding nature of the Development Fee.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract law principles of definite terms and consideration
